Behavioral endocrinologist Frank A. Beach claims in a 1974 letter[9] to have introduced the term "Coolidge effect" in either 1958 or 1959.[10] He attributed the neologism to[11]  an old joke about Calvin Coolidge when he was President ... The President and Mrs. Coolidge were being shown [separately] around an experimental government farm. When [Mrs. Coolidge] came to the chicken yard she noticed that a rooster was mating very frequently. She asked the attendant how often that happened and was told, "Dozens of times each day." Mrs. Coolidge said, "Tell that to the President when he comes by." Upon being told, the President asked, "Same hen every time?" The reply was, "Oh, no, Mr. President, a different hen every time." President: "Tell that to Mrs. Coolidge."  The joke appears in a 1972 book (Aggression in Man and Animals, by Roger N. Johnson, p. 94).[12]

I think he's not quite right on Bonobos. They are less violent than chimps toward other Bonobos, but they can be rather harsh against intruders. Also, the sex isn't totally free. Usually, one female is the most desirable, and the males face a hierarchical pecking order of how desirable they are to females, who they seem to enjoy sex with much more than with each other. Otherwise, Bonobos show a colony pattern like other primate groups, in which makes form a periphery with females in the core. But that core is the dominant part of the colony. It is extremely amusing to watch them constantly getting it on! Sex to quell aggressions when they're hungry. Sex when they find food. Sex while they eat. Sex to celebrate having had food. 29:46 "So does testosterone actually have a causal role in increasing the likelihood of male sexual behavior?" Yes, it does. And it does do so massively:  "Testosterone is critical for sexual desire, function, and arousal in men.[20][21] Aromatization of testosterone into the estrogen estradiol appears to be partially responsible for the effects of testosterone on sexual desire and function in men.[22][23][24] 5α-Reduction of testosterone into the more potent androgen dihydrotestosterone (DHT) may have a small contribution to the effects of testosterone on sexual desire and function in men.[25] Based on animal research, metabolites of DHT including the neurosteroids and weak estrogens 3α-androstanediol and 3β-androstanediol may be involved in sexual function in men.[26][27][28]"  Then, Sapolsky tries to make us believe that - contrary to ALL other hormones - it would not play a role whether we see 10% or 200% of normal testosterone levels.  "But those brain regions are not really all that concerned with the exact level of testosterone." Sorry, but the claim that it would not matter if you have 10% or 200% of normal testosterone levels is utterly, utterly wrong. Actually even little differences seem to matter A LOT:  "Men experience sexual dysfunction at testosterone levels of below 300 ng/dL, with men that have levels of testosterone of approximately 200 ng/dL often experiencing such problems.[29] Complete loss of testicular testosterone production resulting in testosterone levels within the castrate range (95% decrease, to 15 ng/dL on average) with surgical or medical castration causes profound sexual dysfunction in men.[30][31] Combined marked suppression of testicular testosterone production resulting in testosterone levels of just above the castrate/female range (70 to 80% decrease, to 100 ng/dL on average) and marked androgen receptor antagonism with high-dosage cyproterone acetate monotherapy causes profound sexual dysfunction in men.[30][32] Treatment of men with medical castration and add-back of multiple dosages of testosterone to restore testosterone levels (to a range of about 200 to 900 ng/dL) showed that testosterone dose-dependently restored sexual desire and erectile function in men.[33]"  Seriously, I do not understand why Sapolsky tries so hard to talk down the massive importance of testosterone in men's sexuality. Testosterone is absolutely necessary to have any sexual behavior in men. It is even more important than having a sexual partner, such as a woman, as men with high levels in testosterone don't need a partner to engage in sexual behavior.  What would cause/amplify sexual behavior in men even more than testosterone? Good luck in finding that, because all scientists have failed to do that so far.

He tends to overstate the confidence scientist have in a study when it aligns with his beliefs, while he is very dismissive of studies which are much more widely accepted. In the modern 'publish or perish' academic environment, publishing a study with controversial results can be the difference between a researcher getting their foot in the door with a reputable scientific research institution or taking a job as a potato chip seasoning engineer. Make sure you read these studies for yourself, before you repeat what the professor says. John S Yeah, it's all different angles of the same theory. Most cultural norms come from looking at what is most common or works best and drawing an ought from an is, creating a social more from it and demanding that everyone fall in line. 'Just so' stories explain things that occur without promoting competitive reproductive success.   Even if something came about indirectly, but you can demonstrate that its benefits self select and encourage the process which produced it, it's not a spandral anymore. If you can point to where something is clearly advantageous, a load bearing column if you will, it is not a 'just so' story. Spandrals are always nonstructural. I think the professor goes way over the top with his ambiguity emphasis.   And fun factoid, early Christians were not monogamous, as the Bible never forbade polygamy. The Christian church adopted monogamy because it was a requisite Roman cultural norm. Christianity had to adapt to Roman cultural norms, or it never would have spread with the roman empire.   There are several well documented reasons why monogamous relationships produce stronger societies. Another angle is the 'tragedy of the commune' effect on male child rearing. When fathers don't know which children are theirs, they are more willing to help all the children. However, they do not contribute as many resources to all of them as a monogamous father would contribute to his personal child. Kind of like how people don't take care of a public park as well as their own yard. The bigger the social group, the more this is true. And if you keep digging, these types of phenomenon are rooted in general human psychology tendencies which probably evolved from very different causes...

Your comment is frightening. The professor does a great job of compiling a single narrative of what could be happening. However he is not an expert in these fields, and i have noticed several instances where he incorrectly summarizes studies to better fit his narrative. This is a neat series to get people who will never study these subjects thinking, but it is a basic and very flawed introduction to these topics.
I have found his facts and analysis  bulletproof. Your specific example?

coreycox2345 I've noticed several examples of him misanalyzing studies and using vastly different standards for which studies he accepts or rejects. An example is his rejection of separated twin studies, that prove how shockingly little a child's environment effects certain things, with the argument that they shared the same environment in the womb or in the first few hours of life. Those studies are so statistically demonstrative that you are still left with, at best, the conclusion that an enormous amount of what happens after the first few hours outside of the womb is irrelevant.  Another easy example is his understanding of the difference between sex and gender. In a previous lecture he correctly noted that we know the brain region that determines what gender people feel, and we can actually tell what gender someone will identify with by examining their brain regardless of what gender they were raised to be, with transgender people. Now his conclusion is that gender is entirely a function of culturalization in males who's brains do not androgynize that region but instead retain the female form? We know culturalization has virtually nothing to do with gender identity or sexual orientation. There are many other studies on these subjects.   Previously he made the neurologically incoherent claim that transgender people are not people who think they are the wrong sex because their brain tells them they are the opposite gender, they are people who are the wrong sex (or have the wrong body). Transgender people literally think they are the opposite sex. We know that their brain tells them they are, but their thoughts do not make them the 'wrong' sex. Regardless of how you treat it, this is the definition of a psychological disorder, and his statements on it were absurd from a neurological perspective.  I've noticed several errors, usually in drawing questionable conclusions or misplacing the emphasis on what level of effect the conclusion of a study has on the things he is actually talking about. This series is a good starting point if you want to learn about these things. He includes an array of perspectives in his narrative, but you'll have to study these subjects in much greater detail than he presents. There is still too much positivist high priesting in these lectures.
